Fig. 1 HRTEM of (a) CNT (scale bar 5 nm), (b) CNTox (scale bar 10 nm), (c) N-CNT (scale bar 20 nm), (d) S2-CNT (scale bar 20 nm), (e) sCNF (scale bar 10 nm), (f) CNF (scale bar 10 nm), (g) FC (scale bar 5 nm), and (h) FLG (scale bar 5 nm) supports. Fig. 2 (a) Schematic illustration for N2 adsorption on different types of graphitic carbon surfaces. Nitrogen adsorption on (i) basal plane surfaces, (ii) prismatic surfaces, (iii) “defect” surfaces or dislocations leading to surface roughness, and (iv) polar surface groups, which are located at prismatic or “defect” surfaces; (b) DFT surface areas of the materials; and (c) ratios of prismatic:basal:defect surfaces of the materials. The absolute value of the DFT surface area for each material is the sum of the prismatic surface area, the basal plane surface area and the defect surface area (see Table S1 in the SI). Fig. 3 Carbon supports classified according to: (a) sp2/sp3 carbon ratio from XPS and ID/IG from Raman; (b) % of sp2 carbon from XPS and LD from Raman; and (c) IG/IG’ from Raman and the FWHM of the C1s peak from XPS. Fig. 4 (a) Evolution of the metal loading normalized with respect to the specific surface area with SBET; (b) correlation between IG’/ID and metal loading normalized with respect to the specific surface for materials presenting high long-range order; and (c) correlation between IG’/ID and metal loading normalized with respect to the specific surface for materials presenting low long-range order. Fig. 5 HRTEM micrographs of: (a) and (b) Pd/CNTox (scale bars = 50 and 20 nm, respectively); (c) and (d) Pd/FCox (scale bars = 50 and 20 nm, respectively); (e) and (f) Pd/CNFHT; (g) and (h) Pd/sCNFox (scale bars = 50 and 20 nm, respectively). Fig. 6 Correlations between the mean Pd NP size and: (a) LC from XRD, (b) amount of sp2 carbon from XPS; (c) FWHM of the C1s peak from XPS; (d) IG’/IG from Raman; (e) LD from Raman; and (f) ID/IG from Raman. Fig. 7 (a) Palladium loading (red rectangles) and dispersion (black rectangles) obtained for the different carbon supports. The blue rectangles highlight the best compromises between loading and dispersion. (b) Influence of supports characteristics on metal loading and dispersion. Fig. 8 Mean Site Time Yield – STY50 and STY90 of the palladium catalysts for myrcene complete hydrogenation. Myrcene 1 M; heptane 80 mL; 200 mg catalyst; 120 °C °C; 20 bar H2. Fig. 9 Correlations between dispersion combined to oxygen content of the support (from XPS) and mean apparent Site Time Yield – STY90 values of: (a) the entire series of catalysts; (b) Pd/CNT catalyst series; (c) Pd/FLG catalyst series; (d) Pd/FC catalyst series; (e) Pd/sCNF catalyst series; and (f) Pd/CNF catalyst series. Graphical abstract The influence of the carbon support characteristics on Pd loading, dispersion and activity in Pd/C catalysts has been analyzed. Several carbon nanomaterials, including multi-walled CNTs, nitrogen-doped CNTs, sulfur-doped CNTs, large- and small-diameter nanofibers, few-layer graphene, and a fibrous carbon have been produced, functionalized, defunctionalized and characterized using several techniques (e.g., nitrogen adsorption, Raman spectroscopy, XPS, TGA, and elemental analysis). These supports present different surface chemistry, arising from different features (defect concentration, inter-defect distances, long-range order, and orientation of the graphene layers) and specific surface areas. The most relevant parameters were obtained by characterization of the materials by Raman, XPS, nitrogen adsorption, and XRD. Twenty-four palladium catalysts with the same nominal loading (2%w/w) were prepared by wet impregnation using an acetone solution of Pd nitrate. These 24 catalysts were characterized by ICP, XRD, XPS and TEM. The final Pd loading varied between 1 and 2%w/w and the Pd particle size ranged from 1.5 to 3.3 nm, depending on the nature of the support. The parameters influencing both Pd loading and dispersion are discussed, and their very high activity for the myrcene complete hydrogenation are reported. Keywords Palladium Carbon materials Metal dispersion Hydrogenation 1 Introduction Palladium on carbon constitutes an important class of catalysts in the global chemical catalyst market, representing 1.1 billion USD from a market of 7 billion USD [1]. These catalysts are mainly used in liquid-phase hydrogenation, dehydrogenation, oxidation, and CC coupling reactions in the fine chemicals area [2–5]. The most common carbon support is activated carbon (AC), mainly because of its high surface area, broad pore size distribution, and low price. The primary role of a catalyst support is to provide a structural framework, which enables the formation of a highly dispersed active phase, and to increase its stability when submitted to sintering conditions. Nevertheless, the carbon support can also have a direct influence on the course of the catalytic reaction, since its surface might be active toward reactants and/or reaction intermediates and products. In addition, the support can also have an indirect influence because its physicochemical properties may affect the shape and electronic state of the metal, as well as the accessibility of the active sites to reactants. The preparation of Pd/C catalysts has been an active topic of research for many years, focusing particularly on the possibility to draw correlations between the structure of the carbon materials (surface area, porosity, and surface chemistry) and the final Pd dispersion, or, in some cases, the Pd loading [6]. The textural properties of the support, such as specific surface area and porosity, have been found to influence the Pd loading and/or dispersion [7–10]. On ACs, the Pd particle size is mainly determined by the extent of the AC surface in the meso- and macropore range [7,9]. A large mesopore surface area favors high Pd dispersion. Two distinct types of supported Pd species have been evidenced by small angle X-ray scattering (SAXS), wide angle X-ray scattering (WAXS) and X-ray radial distribution function: a well-crystallized phase and a nearly atomic dispersed form, randomly distributed on the carbon support or condensed in small clusters of a few atoms [11]. Next to that, landmark papers by Walker et al. [12,13] and Derbyshire et al. [14] have highlighted the importance of the carbon surface chemistry on metal dispersion. Since then, there has been a growing awareness regarding the importance of the surface chemistry of carbon supports in achieving better catalyst performances. Nevertheless, the knowledge about carbons is lower than that of other supports such as alumina and silica. The variability of the AC properties depending on the raw material is the main reason. In addition, there are several difficulties in the surface characterization of this material [15]. It has been generally admitted that the introduction of oxygenated surface groups on AC, particularly carboxylic groups created during HNO3 oxidation, results in catalysts with higher loadings and dispersions [16]. The introduction of nitrogen-containing groups may induce a similar effect [17]. Interestingly, HCl treatments also have a positive impact on metal dispersion on AC or carbon blacks, and even on graphite [18]. It is worth mentioning that high metal dispersions are not systematically correlated with high catalytic activity [16,19], since the presence of functional groups can have a negative impact on the chemical reaction [20]. In addition, it has also been shown that intensive HNO3 or HCl treatments lead to poor metal precursor distributions on AC [21]. This might be the result of a preferred precursor anchoring on these groups, or of a repelling electrostatic interaction, both hindering the precursor from penetrating the AC porous network. It has also been proposed that severe treatments directly affect the porosity of the supports, which in turn affects the metal dispersion [22]. Other sites are also available for Pd adsorption: basal planes of the carbon network, where adsorption is (relatively) weak [23], graphene edges and large vacancies, where adsorption is strong [24], and micropores, where irreversible adsorption can occur since metallic atoms can interact with two or more carbon networks simultaneously [25]. The role of the edge sites of AC on Pd loading and dispersion has been little studied [26–28], and their exact nature is still under debate [29]. Despite the proposal of the existence of surface carbene- or carbyne-like sites on the edges, their existence under ambient conditions is questionable. It is also worth mentioning that some of these sites might be responsible for spontaneous reduction of Pd salts on the carbon surface [25,30]. The basal planes of carbon, which present Lewis basicity (π-electron-rich regions within the basal planes of carbon crystallites) [31], should be involved in this latter process [32]. Since the beginning of the century, many carbon nanomaterials such as carbon nanotubes (CNTs), nanofibers (CNFs) or graphene-based materials have been investigated as supports in catalysis [33]. These materials show great potential due to the possibility of tailoring their surface properties, and to some extent their mesoporous character. As such, they constitute excellent models, which by eliminating the microporosity as one of the important parameters, allow studying the influence of the preparation procedure of carbon-supported catalysts on the carbon surface structure and chemistry. The microporosity of traditional ACs should be regarded as a disadvantage in their use as catalyst supports. Indeed, despite being accessible to small molecules such as hydrogen, the active sites localized in narrow pores are not easily accessible to bulkier molecules like organic substrates [34], meaning that part of the supported metal is lost for catalysis. Chen et al. have recently reviewed the main findings as far as CNT and CNF supports are concerned [35]: (i) the basal plane/edge ratio is critical for metal loading and dispersion, and (ii) the introduction of basic nitrogen sites improves metal loading and dispersion. However, analysis of the literature data does not allow for unambiguous correlation between catalyst properties (loading, dispersion, performance) and surface pre-treatment conditions of the carbon support. Hence, the aim of this work is to draw general structure/performance correlations between Pd/C catalyst preparation and its use. More precisely, we aim at analyzing the influence of the support characteristics on Pd loading/dispersion, and finally on catalytic activity. Mesoporous supports were used to exclude the influence of microporosity. We focused our analysis on support characteristics such as specific surface area, presence/absence of heteroatoms (O, N, or S), and presence/absence of structural defects, including the “basal-plane” to “non-basal-plane” ratio. Hence, we have produced (de)functionalized and characterized a large spectrum of carbon materials, including multi-walled CNTs, nitrogen-doped CNTs (N-CNTs), sulfur-doped CNTs (S-CNTs), large- (CNFs) and small-diameter (sCNFs) carbon nanofibers, few-layer graphene (FLG), and a fibrous carbon (FC). These materials have been used as supports for Pd deposition. The effect of the chemical, textural, and crystallite properties of the carbon supports on Pd loading and dispersion is first discussed, based on nitrogen adsorption, XRD, TEM, XPS, and Raman analyses. Finally, the catalytic performances of these 24 samples were evaluated for myrcene hydrogenation under batch conditions, and structure/activity correlations are discussed. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation The CNTs, N-CNTs, S-CNTs, FLG, CNFs, and FC were synthesized by catalytic chemical vapor deposition in a fluidized bed reactor using ethylene (C2H4) as a carbon source, acetonitrile (C2H3N) as a carbon and nitrogen source, and thiophene (C4H4S) as a carbon and sulfur source. AlFeCoO4 (CNT, N-CNT, S-CNT), CoFe2O4 (CNF, FLG), 10%Ni/Al2O3 (s-CNF) and Cu0.1Ni0.9Co2O4 (FC) catalysts were used to produce the carbon nanomaterials used in this work. 2.1.1 CNT, CNTox, CNTHT, and CNTox-HT syntheses The AlFeCoO4 catalyst was reduced in the fluidized bed reactor under a nitrogen (225 mL·min−1) and hydrogen (150 mL·min−1) flow at 650 °C. After the reduction step, the ethylene flow was adjusted to 225 mL·min−1 for 30 min to produce CNTs. The CNTs were recovered and then purified using an aqueous solution (50 vol% H2SO4) under reflux at 140 °C for 3 h. The acidic solution was then filtered and the solid washed with distilled water. The resulting solid was dried in an oven at 80 °C overnight. A portion of purified CNTs was then functionalized with HNO3 under reflux at 140 °C for 3 h. The acidic solution was filtered and washed with distilled water. The resulting solid was dried in an oven at 80 °C overnight to produce functionalized CNTs (CNTox). Another portion of purified CNTs was treated in a horizontal tube oven under a nitrogen flow at 1000 °C for 1 h to produce high-temperature-treated CNTs (CNTHT). Finally, a portion of functionalized CNTs (CNTox) was treated in a horizontal tube oven under a nitrogen flow at 1000 °C for 1 h to produce high-temperature-treated functionalized CNTs (CNTox-HT). 2.1.2  N-CNT and N-CNTHT syntheses The AlFeCoO4 catalyst was reduced in the fluidized bed reactor under a nitrogen (225 mL·min−1) and hydrogen (150 mL·min−1) flow at 650 °C. After the reduction step, the nitrogen and hydrogen flows passed through an acetonitrile-containing bubbler (T = 35 °C) for 30 min to produce N-CNTs. The N-CNTs were recovered and then purified using an aqueous solution (50 vol% H2SO4) under reflux at 140 °C for 3 h. The acidic solution was then filtered and washed. The resulting solid was dried in an oven at 80 °C overnight. Finally, a portion of purified N-CNTs was treated in a horizontal tube oven under a nitrogen flow at 1000 °C for 1 h to produce high-temperature-treated N-CNTs (N-CNTHT). 2.1.3 S-CNT and S-CNTHT syntheses Two types of S-CNTs were produced from an AlFeCoO4 catalyst. The AlFeCoO4 catalyst was reduced in the fluidized bed reactor under a nitrogen (225 mL·min−1) and hydrogen (150 mL·min−1) flow at 750 °C. After the reduction step, the nitrogen and hydrogen flows were stopped and thiophene introduced for 30 min to produce S1-CNT. Alternatively, after the reduction step, the nitrogen and hydrogen flows were stopped and ethylene introduced for 3 min, followed by thiophene for 27 min to produce S2-CNT. The S-CNTs were recovered and purified using an aqueous solution (50 vol% H2SO4) under reflux at 140 °C for 3 h. The acidic solution was then filtered and washed. The resulting solid was dried in an oven at 80 °C overnight. Finally, a portion of purified S-CNTs was treated in a horizontal tube oven under a nitrogen flow at 1000 °C for 1 h to produce high-temperature-treated S-CNTs (S-CNTHT). 2.1.4 FLG, FLGox, FLGHT, and FLGox-HT syntheses The CoFe2O4 catalyst was reduced in the fluidized bed reactor under a nitrogen (225 mL·min−1) and hydrogen (150 mL·min−1) flow at 650 °C. After reduction step, the ethylene flow was adjusted to 225 mL·min−1 for 30 min to produce FLG [4]. The FLG was recovered and purified at room temperature overnight using HCl. The acidic solution was then filtered and washed. The resulting solid was dried in an oven at 80 °C overnight. A portion of purified FLG was then functionalized with HNO3 under reflux at 140 °C for 3 h. The acidic solution was filtered and washed. The resulting solid was dried in an oven at 80 °C overnight to produce functionalized FLG (FLGox). Another portion of purified FLG was treated in a horizontal tube oven under a nitrogen flow at 1000 °C for 1 h to produce high-temperature-treated FLG (FLGHT). Finally, a portion of functionalized FLG was treated in a horizontal tube oven under a nitrogen flow at 1000 °C for 1 h to produce high-temperature-treated functionalized FLG (FLGox-HT). 2.1.5 CNF, CNFox, CNFHT, and CNFox-HT syntheses The CoFe2O4 catalyst was reduced in the fluidized bed reactor under a nitrogen (225 mL·min−1) and hydrogen (150 mL·min−1) flow at 450 °C. After the reduction step, the ethylene flow was adjusted to 225 mL·min−1 for 30 min to produce CNFs. The CNFs were recovered and then purified at room temperature overnight using HCl. The acidic solution was then filtered and washed. The resulting solid was dried in an oven at 80 °C overnight. A portion of purified CNFs was functionalized using HNO3 under reflux at 80 °C for 3 h. The acidic solution was then filtered and washed. The resulting solid was dried in an oven at 80 °C overnight to produce functionalized CNFs (CNFox). Another portion from purified CNF was then treated in a horizontal tube oven under a nitrogen flow at 1000 °C for 1 h to produce high-temperature-treated CNFs (CNFHT). Finally, a portion of functionalized CNFs was then treated in a horizontal tube oven under a nitrogen flow at 1000 °C for 1 h to produce high-temperature-treated functionalized CNFs (CNFox-HT). 2.1.6 sCNF, sCNFox, sCNFHT, and sCNFox-HT syntheses Small-diameter carbon nanofibers were prepared using a 10%Ni/Al2O3 catalyst. The synthesis of the sCNFs was carried out in two steps: first, 2 g of 10%Ni/Al2O3 catalyst was reduced in the fluidized bed under a nitrogen (160 mL·min−1) and hydrogen (120 mL·min−1) flow at 650 °C; in the second step, the ethylene flow was adjusted to 60 mL·min−1 for 1 h. The sCNFs were recovered and purified using an aqueous solution (50 vol% H2SO4) under reflux at 80 °C for 3 h. The acidic solution was then filtered and washed. The resulting solid was dried in an oven at 80 °C overnight. A portion of purified sCNFs was then functionalized using HNO3 under reflux at 80 °C for 3 h. The acidic solution was filtered and washed. The resulting solid was dried in an oven at 80 °C overnight to produce functionalized CNF (sCNFox). Another portion of the purified sCNFs was then treated in a horizontal tube oven under a nitrogen flow at 1000 °C for 1 h to produce high-temperature-treated sCNFs (sCNFHT). Finally, a portion of functionalized sCNFs (sCNFox) was treated in a horizontal tube oven under a nitrogen flow at 1000 °C for 1 h to produce high-temperature-treated functionalized sCNFs (sCNFox-HT). 2.1.7 FC, FCox, FCHT, and FCox-HT syntheses The Cu0.1Ni0.9Co2O4 catalyst was reduced in the fluidized bed reactor under a nitrogen (300 mL·min−1) and hydrogen (300 mL·min−1) flow at 675 °C. After the reduction step, the ethylene flow was adjusted to 1000 mL·min−1 for 20 min to produce FC. The FC was recovered and then purified at room temperature overnight using HCl. The acidic solution was filtered and washed. The resulting solid was dried in an oven at 80 °C overnight. A portion of purified FC was then functionalized using HNO3 under reflux at 140 °C for 3 h. The acidic solution was filtered and washed. The resulting solid was dried in an oven at 80 °C overnight to produce functionalized FC (FCox). Another portion of purified FLG was then treated in a horizontal tube oven under a nitrogen flow at 1000 °C for 1 h to produce high-temperature-treated FC (FCHT). Finally, a portion of functionalized FC was treated in a horizontal tube oven under a nitrogen flow at 1000 °C for 1 h to produce high-temperature-treated functionalized FC (FCox-HT). 2.1.8 Pd/carbon catalysts A wet impregnation method was used to prepare the palladium catalysts supported on carbon nanomaterials. The desired amount of palladium(II) nitrate dihydrate [Pd(NO3)2·2H2O] was added to an acetone solution (100 mL) containing 1 g of carbon nanomaterial, so as to introduce 2 %w/w of metal phase. The solution was then sonicated at room temperature for 1 h and magnetically stirred overnight. The solution was then filtered and washed with acetone. The resulting solid was dried in an oven at 120 °C overnight. Finally, the catalyst was reduced in a horizontal tube oven under a nitrogen and hydrogen flow (20 vol% H2) at 300 °C for 2 h (25 °C to 300 °C at 10 °C/min). For comparison purpose in myrcene hydrogenation we also used a commercial 5%Pd/activated carbon catalyst from Alfa Aesar (Johnson Mattey). 2.2 Characterization TEM micrographs were taken with a JEOL JEM 1011 microscope operating at 100 kV. XRD spectra were measured at room temperature with a Panalytical X’PERT PRO diffractometer, employing a Cu-Kα radiation (λ = 1.54 Å) and a parabolic MPD-mirror for Cu radiation. The diffractograms were acquired in 2θ range of 5–90°, using a continuous scan mode with an acquisition step size of 0.0170° and a counting time of 299.72 s. To measure the crystallite size Lc (graphitic stacking), we used the Sherrer’s equation from the 002 line. Raman spectra were recorded with a micro Raman Spectrometer HR 800 Jobin Yvon Horiba using a laser of 532 nm wavelength as an excitation source. The thermograms were acquired in a temperature range of 30–1000 °C at 10 °C min−1 under air using a TG/DTA Shimadzu. Nitrogen adsorption measurements were performed at −196 °C using a 3Flex Surface Characterization Analyzer (Micromeritics GmbH). Before analysis, the samples were degassed at 150 °C using a Micromeritics VacPrep 061 Sample Degas System until a static pressure of less than 0.01 Torr (0.0133 mbar) was reached. The adsorptive potential distributions were calculated from the adsorption isotherms using the standard instrument software (3Flex Version 4.04). The calculation of the DFT, basal plane and “non-basal plane” surfaces as well as of the respective ratios has been performed as described in the literature [36]. The surface chemical composition of the carbon materials was analyzed by XPS (Kratos AXIS Ultra HSA spectrometer), using a Mg-Kα radiation (1486.7 eV). The existing elements, and their corresponding concentrations were determined by recording a survey spectra up to a binding energy (BE) of 1300 eV. High-resolution XPS spectra of the C1s, N1s, O1s, and S2p core levels and full-width-at-half-maximum values were used to assess the chemical state of these elements at the catalyst surface, according to the NIST database. For the C1s peaks, the XPS-spectra fitting was performed introducing the classical parameters (intensity, binding energy, line-width, Gaussian/Lorentzian mixing ratio) for symmetrical lines and the exponential tail parameters for asymmetrical ones. Moreover, the high-resolution C KLL Auger peak was also recorded, using its derivative to determine the sp2/sp3 ratio [37]. The C1s peak (284.6 eV) was taken as an internal standard to correct the shift in BE caused by sample charging. The elemental results were obtained using a CHN Perkin-Elmer elemental analyzer. The palladium loadings were determined. The elemental analyses of palladium were carried out by ICP-OES at the analytical service of the LCC (Laboratoire de Chimie de Coordination) using an iCAP 6300 ICP Spectrometer after aqua regia microwave digestion (three measurements by sample). Palladium particle size distribution was calculated using the ImageJ software on at least 250 particles. 2.3 Myrcene hydrogenation Myrcene catalytic hydrogenation has been carried out in a stirred tank reactor of 200 mL from Top Industrie. This reactor is equipped with 4 baffles and a gas inducing Rushton turbine having 6 straight blades to provide an efficient G-L-S contacting. The tests were operated at 1200 rpm and 120 °C with 200 mg of catalyst powder under pure H2 atmosphere at a constant pressure of 20 bar. The liquid phase consists in 80 mL of a 1M myrcene (Sigma-Aldrich, 98% purity, corresponding to 3M of CC double bond) solution in n-heptane (sigma Aldrich, 99%) containing a known trace of n-tetradecane as internal standard for final GC-FID analysis (DB17 column). In this configuration, the reactor is operated in batch mode for the liquid and solid phases and in semi-batch mode for the gas because hydrogen was constantly fed via a pressure regulator and supplied by a calibrated reserve. The pressure and temperature monitoring of this reserve provides the hydrogen consumption rate, and thus the apparent and instantaneous activity of the catalysts expressed in moles of H2 consumed per moles of surface Pd and per second, and being homogeneous to a Site Time Yield (“STY” in the following). To ensure a reproducible and precise initial times for the tests, heating of the reactor was first done with 1 bar of N2, then agitation was stopped and the N2 atmosphere was replaced by 20 bar of H2 and agitation turned on again, defining the initial time for the experiment. Because the instantaneous STY varies considerably with time in a given experiment (3 hydrogenation reactions and different double-bond reactivity; see Fig. S1 for representative examples with Pd/C, Pd/CNT and Pd/sCNFox catalysts), a fair comparison of the catalysts for the total hydrogenation is done via the definition of a mean Site Time Yield (“STY90”) determined at a constant and high level of substrate hydrogenation of 90% (meaning that 2.7 equivalents of H2 are consumed). These STY90 are not intrinsic and qualified of apparent because first it addresses the overall consumption of H2 through multiple reactions and second because possible external and internal mass transfer resistances are likely for the first CC hydrogenations, which are very fast. Consequently, these activities are also partially depending on the reactor contacting efficiency but reflect still the overall catalyst efficiency to hydrogenate the substrate under identical initial conditions. The STY90 is thus calculated as following: STY 90 = 2.7 × m y r c e n e 0 × V L t 90 × n Pd , s u r f a c e mol H 2 / mol Pd , s u r f a c e / s where VL is the liquid volume, [myrcene]0 is the initial concentration of myrcene, t90 is the time to reach 90% of the maximum hydrogen uptake by the myrcene substrate (here 2.7 equivalents of H2 for the 3CC of myrcene) and nPd,surface is the quantity of surface Pd atoms determined classically with the dispersion and the weight fraction of active phase in the catalysts. No side-reaction like Diels-Alder or oligomerization are encountered in the experimental domain investigated for this myrcene substrate. Thus, no selectivity issue has to be considered. The good matching between the evolution of H2 consumption profiles and of liquid substrate compositions has been checked (not shown here) and validates the experimental approach. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Carbon support characterization All carbon supports were prepared by catalytic chemical vapor deposition in a fluidized bed reactor using optimized catalysts, to produce selectively each kind of nanomaterial. All the supports were heat-treated at 1000 °C in order to modify their electronic properties and chemical structure. CNT, CNF, sCNF, FLG, and FC supports have also been oxidized with nitric acid to increase the concentration of surface carboxylic groups, which can act as anchoring sites for metallic nanoparticles (NPs) [38]. The oxidized samples were also submitted to a high-temperature treatment (HTT) under argon to remove most of the oxygenated groups created during the oxidation (carboxylic, phenol, carbonyl, etc.) [39], particularly the COOH groups. 3.1.1 Support morphology (TEM) Typical HRTEM micrographs of the purified carbon materials used in this study are shown in Fig. 1 . Lower magnification TEM micrographs are shown in Fig. S2. We independently checked that the post-treatments did not have a significant effect on the general morphology of these materials, with the exception of the HNO3 treatment, which causes some surface damage, particularly for small-diameter CNTs (Figs. 1b and S3). These materials show different arrangements of the graphene layers. Among the filamentous carbon materials, we can distinguish between CNT and S-CNT, in which the graphene layers are parallel to the filament axis, and N-CNT, CNF, sCNF, and FC, in which an angle exists between the filament axis and the graphene layers. The average angle with respect to the filament long axis is different, ∼20, ∼26, ∼40, and ∼90° for N-CNT, CNF, sCNF, and FC, respectively. Hence, the surface of these materials should mainly be composed of edges (prismatic planes). As observed for pyrolytic graphite powders or CNFs [40,41], it is reasonable to assume that some of the graphene edges are likely to be closed (see Fig. S4), because of the reduced number of dangling bonds. As far as open edges are concerned (see Fig. S4) they may be easily terminated by OH or COOH under ambient conditions, or more likely by H, since the synthesis of these materials is carried out at high temperature in the presence of hydrogen. Thus, it is very likely that the carbon edges terminate in CH2/CH3 or aromatic CH groups [42]. The presence of highly reactive “carbene-like” (zigzag sites) or “carbyne-like” (armchair sites) vacancies, which has been previously suggested [29], might also be considered, even if it seems unlikely that they remain intact after synthesis and air exposure. In the case of CNF, disordered carbon can be occasionally observed at their surface (Fig. S5), resulting in a mixture of edges and disordered carbon (curved surfaces [43]). This structure is similar to that of the hollow vapor-grown CNFs from Pyrograf Products that show a dual-wall structure. In that industrial material, the core layer is a catalytically-grown hollow fishbone-type carbon fiber, whereas the outer layer consists of disordered, pyrolytically-grown walls, parallel to the main axis of the fiber [44]. The mean external diameter of CNF is 50 nm, and their mean inner diameter is 6 nm. The CNT are multi-walled, with an average external diameter of 15 nm and an internal diameter of 7 nm. They are composed of 5–10 graphene layers. N-CNT [45], S1-CNT, and S2-CNT [46] have mean external diameters of 18, 50, and 15 nm, respectively. The different diameters between S1-CNT and S2-CNT derive from their different preparation procedures (see experimental section). The FC material shows a quite broad diameter distribution, ranging from 50 to 400 nm with an average diameter of about 100 nm. The FLG consists in graphitic flakes of turbostratic carbon of around 1 μm2; the number of graphene layers ranges between 5 and 50 [47]. The results from elemental analysis, specific surface area, XRD, XPS, and TG analyses for all the supports are listed in Table 1 . 3.1.2 Composition, crystallite properties and stability of the supports (elementals analysis, XPS, XRD and TGA) The elemental analyses show a high level of purity for most materials (90–99%), with the exception of S-CNT, which contain a significant amount of residual catalyst (see Fig. S6). This is probably related to the slow growth kinetics of this type of nanotubes [46]. The treatment with nitric acid, for a given type of material, results in a decrease of the amount of residual catalyst, as shown by the TGA and XRD analyses, where a decrease of the residue amount (metallic impurities) is observed (see Figs. S7a and S8). Another effect of the HNO3 treatment is to increase significantly the amount of surface oxygen, as revealed by XPS (Table 1, and Fig. S7a). This does not affect significantly the decomposition temperature of these materials (TGA data). The introduction of N or S in the carbon structure via doping, results in a higher reactivity of the materials towards air oxidation, as shown by the TGA results. The XPS analysis shows that, as expected, the HTT results in a significant decrease of the amount of surface heteroatoms (O, N, or S). A notable exception is the non-oxidized FC material (see Fig. S7b), for which a significant increase of surface oxygen is observed after the HTT. The specific reactivity of the FC material will be discussed later (vide infra Section 3.1.4). For the non-functionalized supports (CNT, FLG, CNF, sCNF, and FC), this treatment results in an increased stability of the materials, as shown by the TG analyses (Table 1, and Fig. S7c). In that case, the HTT results in a surface reconstruction that produces a less reactive surface. However, the same phenomenon is not systematically observed for the functionalized carbons (oxidized materials and S- or N-doped CNTs, Table 1), therefore, the surface reconstruction does not necessarily provide a less reactive surface for these materials. The d002 graphene interlayer distance and the average stacking heights parallel to the fiber axis (Lc) were determined by XRD and are summarized in Table 1. The corresponding diffractograms are given in Fig. S8. The highest intensity for the graphite (0 0 2) peak (2θ = 26°) and therefore d002 values close to the value for graphite (0.335 nm), was observed for the FLG, FC, and sCNF samples. The higher amount of macro-sized defects, indicated by a lower Lc, could be correlated to a higher SBET and/or a higher reactivity (lower temperature of decomposition during air oxidation) of the materials. Although similar tendencies have been reported for carbon blacks [48] and carbon fibers [49], we could not find any correlation between the SBET or the temperature of decomposition (TGA) of the carbon nanomaterials and the Lc value (Fig. S9). 3.1.3 Textural properties of the supports (adsorption data using DFT) The textural properties of the supports have been first evaluated from nitrogen adsorption/desorption isotherms. These carbon materials present pore volumes of 0.2 to 4.1 cm3·g−1 and are predominantly mesoporous. For the filamentous carbons, the pores are arising from interstices between entangled fibers or tubes. The specific surface area of the supports range between 40 and 300 m2·g−1. Type IV isotherms with type H2 hysteresis loops were obtained, suggesting that the supports are mainly mesoporous and contain, as expected, a small number of micropores. The lowest surface area was measured for FLG (40 m2·g−1), whereas the highest was obtained for sCNFox (296 m2·g−1). With the exception of CNF, the HNO3 treatment generally results in an increase of the SBET. Little change in surface area was also observed by Pittman et al. for HNO3 treated vapor-grown CNFs [50], confirming our findings. For CNTs, an increase in SBET after HNO3 treatments has already been reported, and is associated to an opening of tube tips [51]. The HTT induces different effects on SBET, depending on the material. For CNTs, FLG, and CNF, a slight increase in SBET is generally observed after the HTT. Such a phenomenon has already been observed for CNT, and has been attributed to the removal of surface functional groups during the heat-treatment, which could create some porosity [52]. Interestingly, materials such as sCNF and FC, for which the surface should be mainly composed of edges, behave differently. In that case, the HTT induces a decrease of SBET for the pristine materials, and has no effect on the oxidized materials. It has been shown that the graphitization of CNFs does not affect their morphology, but contributes to the formation of loops, connecting the edges of the graphene sheets [53–55]. A decrease of SBET for CNF after heat-treatment has already been observed [56,57], which could be associated with the increase of the degree of structural order because of the removal of the structural defects. Since the ratio between the basal plane and “non-basal plane” surface areas should be an important factor in determining the surface reactivity of these materials [35], we used DFT calculations, derived from nitrogen adsorption data, for the determination of surface heterogeneities of pristine and heat-treated CNT, FLG, FC, CNF, and sCNF by adsorptive potential distribution [58]. Thus, the absolute and relative extents of “basal plane” and “non-basal plane” surface areas can be determined by a simple nitrogen adsorption measurement, followed by an evaluation of the adsorption data using DFT [36]. The “non-basal plane surfaces” can be further subdivided into “prismatic surfaces” and “defect surfaces” (the latter contain surface groups and other surface defects, as depicted on Fig. 2 a) [59]. Fig. 2 also depicts the DFT surface areas of these materials as well as the ratios of prismatic: basal: defect surfaces. In general, the differences between the BET and DFT surface areas can be explained by the different assumptions that are made in the corresponding theories. For example, the BET theory assumes that the particle surface is homogeneous and therefore does not consider any surface heterogeneities or the influence of surface groups. For all materials, the effect of the HTT is to increase the proportion of basal planes compared to “non-basal planes” (Fig. 2c). This is consistent with the TG analyses that show that the heat-treated supports are less reactive (Table 1, and Fig. S7c). As expected, FC and sCNF, due to their structure, present mainly prismatic surface areas, whereas CNF also present a significant amount of defects. This could be related to the surface of the CNF being composed of a mixture of edges and disordered carbon, as already discussed (Fig. S5). The highest proportion of basal surface area is observed for CNTs, followed by FLG. The fact that the produced FLG flakes present a significant amount of layers (5–50) and a low surface (1 μm2) could explain this result. 3.1.4 Structural order of the supports (XPS and Raman) The Raman and detailed XPS characterizations of the carbon supports are reported in Tables 2 and 3 . Raman spectroscopy is extensively used for investigating, and measuring quantitatively and qualitatively the structural disorder in carbon materials [60,61]. In spite of these advantages, Raman spectroscopy has certain inherent limitations in detecting certain defects in these materials such as charged impurities, perfect edges, and intercalants, as they are not accounted as defects in the D band. Furthermore, the defects caused by surface functional groups do not have any significant footprint in Raman spectra. XPS, in addition to ascertain chemical composition and bonding environment, can also provide useful information about defects and disorder in carbon materials [62]. The presence of defects and functional groups in these materials introduce new peaks and alter the peak position and line-width of C 1s peak. The best fit for the main C1s spectrum was obtained by deconvoluting the profile into seven line shapes (Fig. S10), and their respective parameters are given in Table 2. Peak I, at around 283.7 eV, is attributed to the presence of point defects, which could arise from C vacancies, pentagon and heptagon rings, Stone-Wales defects, or formation of fullerene-like structures [63–65]. Peak II, at 284.6 eV, corresponds to sp2 CC bonds in the regions containing only unmodified C rings at the surface or in deeper layers. Peak III, at 285.1–285.2 eV, is assigned to sp3 carbon species [66]. The peaks at 286.0–286.2 (IV), 287.3–287.5 (V), and 288.4–289.2 eV (VI), correspond to carbon atoms attached to different oxygen-containing groups [67,68]. Finally, the π-π∗ transition loss peak is detected at 290.6–291.2 eV; it typically comprises 15–18% of the total sp2 signal. For the N-doped materials, from the component centered at 286.4 eV, it is not possible to distinguish the contribution of the C-OH groups from that of the C-N bonds, which are known to give a characteristic signal [69]. Moreover, the carbonyl component at 287.5 eV overlaps with that of the NCOH groups. The component at the high BE tail (BE = 289.0 eV) can be related to the presence of strong electron-withdrawing groups, such as formamide-like fragments (NCO). The full width at half-maximum (FWHM) of the C 1s peak has been used to assess the graphitic nature of carbons, with a larger FWHM corresponding to a more disordered structure [70]. A poor correlation is observed between the Lc (from XRD) and the FWHM (Fig S11). Raman spectroscopy was also used to evaluate the degree of structural order of the different carbon materials. It is complementary to XRD, although it has the advantage of surface specificity, thus allowing the study of very heterogeneous materials. A commonly calculated Raman parameter is the ratio between the integrated intensities of the D band (ID) at ∼1380 cm−1, attributed to the defects of the graphitic structure, and G band (IG) at ∼1580 cm−1, which is ascribed to a graphitic (ordered) structure, both bands belonging to the first-order Raman spectrum for carbon materials. Obviously, the graphitic character will reduce the intensity of the D band, therefore decreasing the ID/IG ratio. The degree of structural order estimated by this technique concerns the bi-dimensional features, being strongly dependent on the orientation of the crystallites, whereas the three-dimensional order is interrogated by XRD. Disorder is also responsible for the changes in the intensities of other bands, such as D′ and G′, and also affects the position and shape of the Raman peaks. The G’ band is indicative of long-range order and arises from the two-phonon, second-order scattering process, resulting in the creation of an inelastic phonon [71,72]. Finally, another parameter, measurable by Raman spectroscopy, which is relevant to catalyst preparation, is the LD; LD is a typical inter-defect distance, with the defect being a point-like (zero-dimensional) structure [73]. Poor correlations between the LC and the Raman parameters were obtained (Fig. S12). A comparative study on defect estimation using XPS and Raman spectroscopy in few layer nano-graphitic structures has shown good correlations between these two techniques [63]. In our case, good correlations were found between the IG’/IG or IG’/ID and the FWHM of the C1s peak of the sp2 carbon (Fig. S13c and d). The % of sp2 carbon from XPS does not lead to significant correlations (Fig. S14). Figs. S11–S14 show that the best correlations were obtained between XPS and Raman analyses. Hence, we decided to use these two techniques to classify the numerous carbon materials investigated. Fig. 3 shows the classification of the supports according to the Raman and XPS parameters. From Fig. 3a and b, we notice that we can distinguish two groups of materials according to their characteristics: (i), FLG and CNTs (pristine or doped with nitrogen or sulfur), present less defects (low sp3/sp2 ratio or ID/IG) and a relatively large LD, and (ii) the fibrous carbon and to a lower extent the CNFs, with opposite characteristics. However, the more interesting results are shown on Fig. 3c–d, where differences in long-range order appear more clearly with the IG’/IG (or IG’/ID) and FWHM parameters. From Fig. 3, it is clear that FLG, pristine CNT, and S2-CNT present very different characteristics from the other materials. On these carbon supports, a significantly higher degree of long-range order is expected. This long-range order has a significant influence on the resistance of the materials towards air oxidation. Thus, we find good correlations between the IG’/IG (or IG’/ID) or FWHM values and the temperature of decomposition obtained during the TGA experiments (Fig. S15). Such correlations are weaker when considering parameters such as the LC (from XRD), ID/IG or LD values (Fig. S16). A significantly higher extent of long-range order may also have a pronounced influence on the basicity of these materials. Indeed, it has been pointed out that the π electrons of basal planes of graphene layers could act as Lewis bases [31,70,74,75]. Our results also show that, although CNTs present a higher percentage of basal planes than FLG (vide supra) they also present a lower inter-defect distance (LD) and long-range order (IG’/IG). This result is important since the size of the basic structural units, which should be larger on FLG, can affect catalyst preparation. A quantification of this long-range order can also be made from the graphitic in-plane microcrystallite size, La , which can be obtained from X-ray diffraction [76], or Raman spectroscopy [77]. Fig. S17 shows the evolution of La according to the type of carbon nanomaterial. It is clear that CNT, and particularly FLG, show a significantly higher extent of long-range order. We have already seen that one effect of the HTT is to significantly decrease the amount of surface heteroatoms (O, N or S), except for the non-functionalized FC material. Another expected effect of this treatment is the decrease of the amount of defects in the materials. Fig. S18 depicts the effect of this treatment on structural parameters such as ID/IG, IG’/IG, or the amount of sp2 carbon from XPS. A decrease of the ID/IG ratio and an increase of the amount of sp2 carbon and long-range order (IG’/IG) after HTT were generally observed. The clearest exception comes from FC that presents edges with an angle of 90° with respect to the fiber axis, and no surface basal planes (see DFT). For this material, the amount of sp2 carbon detected by XPS decreases significantly after the heat-treatment, with a concomitant increase of the sp3 carbon and ID/IG ratio (Fig. S19). We can tentatively attribute this phenomenon to the reactivity of the edges, which might favor loop formation upon heating. The carbon hybridization in these curved structures should be between sp2 and sp3, as in fullerene C60 where a 2.28 hybridization has been estimated [78]. This phenomenon is less pronounced on sCNF, and not visible on CNF. This might be correlated to the different average angle with respect to the filament axis: 26, 40, and 90° for CNF, sCNF, and FC, respectively. The higher this angle, the higher is the propensity to form loops. A higher chemical reactivity (proton affinity) has already been proposed by Chen et al. for CNFs presenting different average angles with respect to the filament axis; there, a higher angle also results in a higher reactivity [35]. This could also explain the fact that after HTT, re-oxidation of the FC material upon air exposure occurs easily to produce a material with higher amount of oxygen surface species than before the HTT. For FC, the HTT should create active surface species, which are easily oxidized upon air exposure. An important effect of nitric acid oxidation, which is regularly performed on carbon materials to improve metal adhesion, is to increase the amount of surface oxygen groups, particularly carboxylic groups. For all the investigated supports, an increase of peak VI (carboxylic acids and lactones) from the C1s XPS spectra is observed after HNO3 oxidation (see Fig. S20). The introduction of oxygenated surface groups in carbon nanomaterials is generally associated to an increase of disorder. For CNT and FLG, we observed an increase of ID/IG and a decrease of LD, which is consistent with an increase of the disorder in these materials upon oxidation (see Fig. S20). Such a phenomenon has already been reported in the literature [39,79]. However, an opposite evolution was observed for the supports showing a low basal- to “non-basal-plane” ratio. A decrease of the ID/IG ratio upon nitric oxidation of CNFs has already been reported [80]. In their work, the authors proposed that the small amount of amorphous carbon that is deposited on the CNF during their synthesis is almost completely removed during the oxidation process. It is also possible that the acidic oxidation cuts off the closed loop ends on the surface of CNF, consequently improving the overall alignment of the hexagonal planes (becoming more graphitic), because a nano-sized loop end must present an increased reactivity [81]. The investigated supports reflect the broad spectrum of carbon nanomaterials available for Pd/C catalyst preparation. They are characterized by a different surface chemistry, arising from: i) the presence/absence of oxygen-, sulfur-, or nitrogen-bearing surface groups, which can contribute to the stabilization of the metal precursor or metallic NPs, ii) different concentrations of defects illustrated by different ID/IG ratios, different inter-defect distances (LD), or different long-range orders illustrated by different IG’/IG ratios, which can also affect metal deposition, and iii) different orientations of the graphene layers (different “basal plane” to “non-basal plane” ratios), which allow metal deposition either on the flat (FLG) or curved (CNT) graphitic layers, or on the edges (CNF and FC). These supports are also characterized by different specific surface area, which is an additional parameter that can affect metal dispersion. We thus dispose of a large panel of supports with different characteristics (textural, structural, electronic, surface chemistry) varying in a progressive way (see Fig. S21) to study the influence of these characteristics, first on palladium loading and dispersion, and then on the catalytic activity. 3.2 Palladium catalyst characterization The 2%w/w Pd catalysts were prepared by wet impregnation using an acetone solution of Pd nitrate. This precursor was preferred over other salts because its reduction yields impurity-free Pd particles. After impregnation, the solvent was removed by filtration so that only the Pd interacting with the support remained for the subsequent drying and reduction steps. In acetone, molecular interactions between the surface and the precursor should be predominant factors that will affect loading and dispersion. We independently verified that in our conditions (acetone solvent), the point of zero charge (PZC) for CNT (PZCCNT = 6.9; PZCN-CNT = 6.3; PZCCNT-COOH = 2.2) has no influence on Pd loading or dispersion. Indeed, CNTCOOH and N-CNT present very different PZC values, while showing similar loadings and dispersions (Table 4 ). Palladium deposition was performed on all the carbon supports except for S2-CNT. Table 4 shows the characterization results of the Pd supported catalysts. The specific surface area of the catalysts did not change significantly compared to the bare supports, except for the sCNF supports, for which a significant increase of the SBET was measured for all the Pd catalysts except sCNFox-HT (see Fig. S22). This SBET increase could have taken place due to the reduction of the metallic precursor, and H-spillover [22]. Hydrogen dissociated over the support could either remain adsorbed at the carbon surface, or promote the reduction of surface oxygen groups and hydrogasification reactions, thus, creating additional porosity. This atomic hydrogen hydrogasifies the most reactive and unsaturated carbon atoms at much lower temperatures than molecular hydrogen does. Although hydrogasification usually occurs at higher temperatures (the catalysts were reduced at 300 °C for 2 h), it might also be metal-catalyzed [82]. Concerning the specific behavior of sCNF, it might be related to a higher amount of specific sites with higher reactivity [82]. Thus, it has been shown that from both the thermodynamic and kinetic point of view, methane formation is much easier on zigzag edges than on armchair ones [83]. This latter phenomenon could contribute to a SBET increase. In the case of carbon black, drastic increase in surface area during hydrogasification has been reported, and porosity development was the most plausible explanation [84]. We verified by HTREM (see Fig. S23) that no significant structural modification was caused during catalyst preparation. 3.2.1 Influence of the support on Pd loading The theoretical Pd loading was 2%w/w; ICP analyses on the catalysts have shown loading ranging between 1 and 2% w/w (Table 4 and Fig. S24a). The loading was also normalized with respect to the specific surface area (Fig. S24b). Intuitively, higher Pd loadings could be obtained on supports presenting higher surface areas, and a significant defect concentration (heteroatoms or structural defects) that could act as anchoring centers for the Pd precursor. For impregnations from aqueous precursor solutions, the metal precursor needs to be selected based on the carbon-surface charge, to achieve proper adsorption, since the adsorption is mainly driven by electrostatic attractions [6]. When neutral complexes are used with organic solvents, interaction will occur with specific surface sites of the supports. In both cases the introduction of heteroatoms (O, N, or S) results in higher loadings [35,46]. It has been shown that carboxylic groups [38], ethylamine groups [85], as well as pyridinic N-functional groups [86], are able to stabilize metallic centers. Our results confirmed these findings, since we systematically measured higher Pd loadings on functionalized surfaces, regardless of the heteroatoms present. Furthermore, removal of these heteroatoms by HTT results in a significant decrease of the Pd loading, regardless of the support (Fig. S24a). This latter effect is particularly marked on N- and S-doped materials, and not so pronounced on oxidized materials. For non-functionalized supports, the effect of the HTT on metal loading varies with the support. For CNT, FLG and FC, the HTT has not a significant effect on the Pd loading, whereas for CNF and s-CNF, the HTT results in a significant decrease of the loading. For these two supports, the HTT results in the creation of loops due to an edge rearrangement and low concentration of heteroatoms, which does not correspond to a favorable surface for Pd adsorption. It is worth noting that FC should also present a similar behavior, but in that case, as already stated, significant amount of oxygenated surface species are present, even after HTT. This could explain the absence of an HTT effect on the Pd loading for this material. This result confirms that the reactivity of the sites created by the HTT (loops) is different for FC, sCNF, and CNF, and should be related to the angle with respect to the filament axis. The FC material with an angle of 90°, should present a higher propensity to form loops than CNT and s-CNF, and these loops should present a much higher reactivity than the ones formed in lower amounts on CNT and s-CNF. However, no general correlation was found between the percentage of surface heteroatoms (as measured by XPS) and the Pd loading, or the metal loading normalized with respect to the specific surface area of the materials (Fig. S25). No correlation can be found between the specific surface area and the Pd loading (Fig. S26a), but a correlation exists between the SBET and the metal loading normalized with respect to the specific surface area of the materials. Lower specific surface areas of the support result in higher metal loadings normalized with respect to the specific surface area (Fig. 4 a). This result is not intuitive, and shows that normalized Pd loading can be high on supports with low surface area. We independently checked that the higher normalized Pd loading obtained was not systematically associated to a higher density of Pd NPs per m2 of the support (Fig. S26b and c). We also tried to correlate, but without any success, the Pd loading, or the Pd loading normalized with respect to the specific surface area, with the relevant structural parameters discussed in Section 3.1, such as the FWHM of the C1s XPS peak or the IG’/IG and IG’/ID ratio extracted from the Raman analyses (Fig. S27). The absence of any simple trend between the Pd loading, or the metal loading normalized with respect to the specific surface area, with most of the parameters discussed in the previous section confirms that many interconnected parameters have to be considered. An attempt to correlate the Pd loading, or the metal loading normalized with respect to the specific surface area, with other structural parameters such as LC from XRD, ID/IG ratio from Raman, or sp2/sp3 ratio from XPS (as performed by Chen et al. [35]) was also unsuccessful (Fig. S28). A slight increase of the metal loading normalized with respect to the specific surface area with parameters such as LD or % of sp2 carbon, which are supposed to reflect the structural order in the material, was observed (Fig. S29). This result also is not intuitive, and shows that the normalized Pd loading can be high on supports with high structural order. This increase of Pd loading is not accompanied by a higher density of Pd NPs per m2 of support (Fig. S29). Thus, a support presenting a low surface area and a low density of defects, such as FLG, can yield a higher metal loading (Pd loading = 1.76%w/w) than a support presenting a high surface area and a large number of defects and surface oxygen species, such as sCNFox (Pd loading = 1.69%w/w). On the other hand, the NP density is higher on sCNFox than on FLG; this result is consistent with a higher diffusion rate of the Pd atoms during catalyst activation on FLG, which presents a lower defect density. The relatively high loading obtained on FLG should be correlated to the higher extent of long-range order on this support. Indeed, it is known that delocalized π-electrons present on the basal planes are abundant enough to represent an important percentage of the basic sites present on carbon supports. On non-functionalized support, the contribution of other basic sites such as pyrone-type, chromene, diketone or quinone groups [87] should be negligible. The presence of defects or oxygen groups influences the distribution of these mobile π electrons [88], and induces a decrease of the basicity. These delocalized π-electrons could be involved in the adsorption of the Pd precursor, or in the spontaneous reduction of the Pd precursor. Indeed, it is known that certain inorganic salts can be spontaneously reduced on the carbon basal surface to yield metallic particles [25,32,89,90]. These results led us to reconsider the trends on Pd loading according to the type of carbon supports, as defined from Fig. 3c and d (presence or absence of long-range order). Among the different parameters investigated, IG’/ID was the most relevant to observe possible trends with the Pd loading. For materials showing a high long-range order (typically IG’/ID ≥ 0.39), an increase in IG’/ID induces an increase of the metal loading normalized with respect to the specific surface area (Fig. 4b). On these materials, the reducing properties of the basal planes should be strong enough to reduce spontaneously the metallic precursor. For materials showing a low IG’/ID (≤0.39), an opposite trend is observed (Fig. 4c), as the surface basal planes should not correspond to efficient sites for precursor adsorption and/or reduction. 3.2.2 Influence of the support on Pd dispersion The palladium NP size was evaluated using TEM micrographs. Metal dispersion was evaluated from a universal mathematical relation between the mean relative size of metallic crystallites and their dispersion, as described elsewhere [91]. The dispersion values correlate well with the ones obtained with another equation for metal dispersion from TEM assuming a spherical particle geometry, as described elsewhere [92] (see Fig. S30). Representative TEM micrographs, and NP size distributions are shown in Fig S31, and representative HRTEM micrographs of selected samples are shown in Fig. 5 . It is worth mentioning that for supports presenting an inner cavity, such as CNT and CNF, some particles should be located inside the cavity, particularly for oxidized samples, for which the cavities have been opened by the nitric acid treatment [93]. Even if few large particles are present on most of the samples, the NP size distribution is generally relatively narrow, except for Pd/FCox, for which a bimodal distribution was observed. Once the Pd loading is fixed, the metal dispersion should be related to the proportion of defects; a large number of defects will favor Pd anchoring and limit the surface diffusion, thus favoring high dispersion. The trends we observed for various parameters representative of order/defect follow very roughly this direction (Fig. 6 ). The only reasonable correlation (R2 > 0.5) was obtained again with Raman parameters, in particular the ID/IG ratio and LD. XRD analyses were also performed (Fig. S32). The diffraction peak of Pd(1 1 1) corresponds to particle sizes ranging between 5 and 15 nm, depending on the support. This peak was not observed for samples oxidized with nitric acid or on N-CNT, evidencing a better dispersion of the metallic phase on the oxidized or N-doped supports. The only exception was the FCox support, for which the Pd(1 1 1) diffraction peak was observed. The presence of a bimodal particle size distribution on FCox (Figs. S31o and S32a for STEM-HAADF) might be related to the co-existence of two routes for the formation of Pd0 particles. According to Likholobov et al. [25], metal NPs in a Pd/C catalyst could have two origins: some large ones are formed initially during the impregnation of carbon with the Pd precursor by spontaneous reduction, while the other particles (much smaller) appear only when the precursor is reduced. As already discussed, the formation of Pd NPs by spontaneous reduction will be favored on supports showing high long-range order. As expected, we observed a significant number of large (9–16 nm) Pd NPs on the FLG and FLGHT supports (Fig. S31i and j), which shows significant long-range order. We independently confirmed that Pd particles were present on this support before the catalyst was dried at 120 °C and reduced at 300 °C (Fig. S34a). In that case, the Pd particles were smaller (2–6 nm) than the ones observed on the reduced catalyst, pointing to a sintering effect under reduction conditions. This result is not surprising on FLG, a support showing long-range order and large LD. It was more surprising to find relatively high amounts of large Pd NPs on an oxidized support such as FCox, since this support contains mainly edges (Fig. S33b). The reduction of Pd salts using bases such as polyaniline to yield Pd NPs has already been reported [94]; and some oxygen-containing groups like γ-pyrone-type, chromene, diketone or quinone are assumed to have a basic nature [87]. In particular, theoretical calculations have shown that γ-pyrone-type groups should be significantly more basic than basal planes that contribute to carbon basicity by means of π-cation interactions, and that these groups are clearly strong bases according to the Brönsted definition [95]. However, we independently checked by TPD (Fig. S35) that the FCox did not contain a significantly higher concentration of γ-pyrone-type groups than FLGox or CNTox. Additionally, we did not find Pd particles on the FCox support before the reduction step (Fig. S34b). On AC supports, a better Pd dispersion is generally obtained upon nitric acid oxidation. However it has also been reported that an excessively large amount of oxygen-containing groups [20], arising from the increase of HNO3 concentration, results in a dispersion decrease together with bimodal NP size distribution [96]. It has been proposed that the AC pretreatment with a high HNO3 concentration would result in oxygen-containing groups assembling densely on the AC. The formation of a strong interaction between the acidic oxide groups and the Pd metal precursor should strongly affect the Pd dispersion. This phenomenon should prevail on the FCox support. The discrepancy between the particle size measured by TEM (≤3.3 nm) and XRD (5–15 nm) should be related to the presence, for some samples, of few large particles which dominate the XRD diffractograms, together with many very small particles. In those samples, the basicity of the support should be high enough to spontaneously reduce the Pd precursor, providing few large particles that strongly contribute to the Pd(1 1 1) diffraction peak. Fig. 7 a displays the metal loading (nominal loading of 2%w/w) and dispersion for the investigated catalysts. The best compromises between a high loading and a high dispersion were obtained on supports presenting heteroatoms (O, N, or S), regardless of the carbon nanomaterial. Fig. 7b resumes the effect of support characteristics (textural, structural, electronic, surface chemistry) on the palladium loading and dispersion. An ideal support to combine high loading and dispersion should present; i) a high surface area without microporosity and with a significant proportion of prismatic surface and/or defects (to avoid Pd spontaneous reduction on the basal plane), and ii) a significant proportion (but not to high concentration) of heteroatoms such as oxygen. Thus, it is not surprising that a support such as sCNFox that combine most of these characteristics should be a good candidate to prepare an efficient Pd catalyst. 3.3 Myrcene hydrogenation The easily available acyclic monoterpene β-myrcene is a renewable compound suitable for sustainable transformations to useful chemicals [97]. The main reaction pathway for the hydrogenation of β-myrcene is presented in Scheme 1 [98,99]. Its complete hydrogenation yields 2,6-dimethyloctane, a compound that can be used as blending agent in diesel fuels [100]. The complete hydrogenation includes the hydrogenation of the hard to reduce internal CC bond (Scheme 1). Palladium catalysts have been found to be active for myrcene hydrogenation [98,99,101–103], with reported STY of 11 s−1 on Pd/C for mono-hydrogenated product formation (75 °C, 6 bar H2) [101]. It is worth mentioning that transfer limitations may occur so that the reaction can go intrinsically faster. Complete hydrogenation to 2,6-dimethyloctane requires longer reaction times, resulting in significantly lower STY. With a conventional 10% Pd/C catalyst, complete hydrogenation was reported in cyclohexane after 30 min of reaction at 80 °C and 20 bar (1 wt% of the catalyst, myrcene 8 mmol, STY of 43.5 h−1 based on total Pd) [103]. The catalytic performances of the 24 Pd/C catalysts were evaluated for β-myrcene hydrogenation at 120 °C and 20 bar in heptane and compared to a commercial 5%Pd/C. Blank experiments were performed to rule out a possible activity of the supports. The Site Time Yield at 50 and 90% conversion – STY50 and STY90 (see experimental section) of all catalysts are given in Fig. 8 . Selectivity towards 2,6-dimethyloctane was total for all the investigated catalysts. Several general and interesting tendencies can be extracted from this figure. First, at 50% conversion, which corresponds to the hydrogenation of the easy to reduced CC bonds (terminal and conjugated CC bonds), the activity of many catalysts is very high. In this regime, mass transfer limitation does occur; so the STY50 data are not relevant to draw structure/activity performances. At 90% conversion, the STY of most catalysts is significantly reduced since it corresponds to the hydrogenation of the hard to reduce internal CC bond (see Fig. S1 for representative examples). Second, there is a pronounced influence of the nature of the support on the specific activity of the catalysts; the STY90 varies from 5 s−1 to 565 s−1 depending on the support. It is also interesting to note that very high STYs are obtained under these conditions. Direct STY comparisons with the literature may be hazardous due to differences in experimental domain (T, P, C, etc.), but also in STY definition (vs H2 or substrate, surface or total Pd atoms, etc…) and determination (instantaneous or mean value, different level of conversion, etc…). Moreover, as already evoked here, due to possible G-L and internal mass transfer limitations, the values are reactor dependent. Nonetheless, the apparent STY reported here appear extremely high compared to the ones reported in the literature, indicating a very attractive combination of catalyst activity, experimental conditions and reactor performances. We studied the Pd stability for the Pd/CNTox catalyst. After reaction, we did not detect a significant sintering of palladium, since the mean Pd particle size increases only from 2.2 ± 1.1 nm before catalysis to 2.8 ± 1.7 nm after the catalytic test (Fig. S36). Third, it is also clear that for a given support, the nature of the pre-treatment undergone by the support also has a significant effect on the specific activity of the catalyst. In particular, we have noticed that for a given support, the presence of high amounts of oxygen usually enables higher STY90. For CNTs, nitrogen or sulfur doping yields lower specific activity compared to oxygen doping, even if a higher metal dispersion is obtained. Finally, it seems that the use of supports showing high long-range order (typically, CNT and FLG) results in catalysts with a lower specific activity. Since Pd particle size ranged from 1.5 to 3.3 nm in this catalyst series (mesoporous supports), we could expect a correlation between the STY90 and the dispersion values. However, this is not the case (see Fig. S37a). Attempts to combine dispersion and oxygen percentage (from XPS) values, or dispersion and oxygen percentage and FWHM values (from XPS) with the STY900 values lead to weak correlations (Fig. 9 a and Fig. 38a, respectively). Since an electronic effect of the support could play a role [104], we examined the possibility of a direct correlation between the position of the Pd(0) peak from XPS, which is informative on a possible charge transfer, and the STY90. No correlation was found (Fig. S39a). However, as reported in [104] we found a correlation between the position of the Pd(0) peak from XPS and the Pd NP size for a given treatment of the support (Fig. S40). The binding energy upshift of Pd 3d5/2 when reducing Pd particle size can be ascribed to more electrons transferring from Pd to the carbon support [104]. We also checked a possible correlation between the Pd(0)/Pdox ratio as determined by XPS and the STY90; but again no correlation was found (Fig. S39b). Attempts to combine these values with dispersion did not lead to any correlation either (Fig. S39c and d). As no general structure/activity correlation could be drawn for the entire series of catalysts, we examined each type of carbon material individually. Weak correlations were obtained between dispersion and STY90 values (Fig. S37), with the exception of the Pd/FC series (Fig. S37d), where a correlation exists. This peculiar result is related to the fact that for the FC series, all supports contain significant amounts of oxygen (>6.5% at.), and hence this parameter does not need to be considered to explain the STY90 values. By combining the Pd dispersion and oxygen content of the original supports, strong correlations were obtained for CNT, FLG, FC and sCNF supports (Fig. 9). Similar correlations were also obtained for the same supports by combining the Pd dispersion, oxygen content of the support and FWHM (Fig. S38). No correlation was obtained for the CNF. It is interesting to note that the stronger correlations were obtained for the supports showing long-range order (CNT and FLG). For the other supports (FC, CNF and sCNF), the strength of the correlation decreases with the decrease of the average angle between the filament axis and the graphene layers, and so with the reactivity of the edges. Finally, since the presence of potentially reactive sites (edges and defects) on the support seems to significantly affect the intrinsic catalytic activity of the catalysts, we integrated in the correlation the values of the non-basal plane surfaces (prismatic surfaces and defect surfaces) for each type of untreated carbon materials, together with percentage of oxygen on the catalyst surface determined by XPS and dispersion values. Thus, a very strong correlation was obtained (Fig. 10 ). The introduction of the dispersion values in the correlation and its impact on apparent and instantaneous activity is not surprising, and direct correlations have already been reported for hydrogenation reactions [105,106]. The influence of the percentage of oxygen on the carbon support over the catalytic performance has been reported for hydrogenation reactions of aromatic substrates [107–109]. In that case, the presence of oxygen functionalities on the support induces a decrease of the reaction rate, since it affects the adsorption of the substrate. In our case, these groups have a positive impact on the STY90. Another role of the surface oxygen groups could be to modify the electronic state of palladium. However, we did not find any correlation between the amount of surface oxygen and the Pd0/Pdox surface ratio (see Fig. S41a). We propose that the presence of acidic sites on the support, such as remaining carboxylic groups, could assist alkene isomerization from hard-to-reduce internal CC bonds of myrcene into more easily reducible terminal CC bonds. This should result in increased STY90 values. Finally, the role of the non-basal plane surface of the carbon support on the catalytic performance has been much less documented. Here, we could expect an electronic effect of the support on the metal. However, we did not find any increase of the metallic palladium amount with an increase of the non-basal plane surface (see Fig. S41b). The practical role of these defects has not yet been clarified, and it requires further studies. 4 Conclusions The aim of this work was to analyze the effect of the chemical, textural and crystallite properties of the carbon supports on Pd loading and dispersion in Pd/C catalysts, as well as to evaluate the catalytic performance of these catalysts for myrcene hydrogenation. In light of our work, a number of general conclusions can be drawn, depending on the type of support. Carbon nanotubes. CNTs constitute an interesting support since they possess several characteristics favoring high loading and good dispersion. First, their SBET is large enough and their LD short enough to ensure a good metal dispersion (around 50%), except for CNTHT, which show a very low oxygen content. Second, this support presents a high proportion of basal plane surface combined with a relatively short inter-defect distance (LD), except again for CNTHT. These two characteristics should contribute to the relatively high Pd loading obtained on this support. Third, the possibility to easily introduce heteroatoms on their surface (either by HNO3 oxidation, or by doping – N and S), contributes to both high dispersion and high loading. On this support, the highest loading was obtained for CNTox whereas the highest dispersion was observed for S1-CNT, the best compromise between loading and dispersion being obtained for CNTox. For carbon nanotubes presenting an opened inner cavity, the possibility of having confined Pd particles should be taken into consideration, particularly because it is known that confined particles often present a different catalytic activity and/or selectivity than the ones present on the external surface [110]. Few layer graphene. The FLG produced in this study is relatively thick and thus, presents a relatively low surface area and a moderate proportion of basal plane surface. Additionally, compared to CNT, FLG presents a lower density of structural defects and thus, a longer inter-defect distance. This longer distance (FLG shows the highest LD values) allows a better diffusion of Pd atoms on the support surface, which results in a lower metal dispersion. This phenomenon can be limited by the introduction of oxygenated groups (HNO3 oxidation) on the FLG surface. High LD values should also contribute to a higher basicity of the basal plane surface, favoring Pd auto-reduction and thus, leading to relatively high metal loadings if we consider the low surface area of this support (40–75 m2·g−1). Carbon nanofibers and fibrous carbon. Three carbon materials, for which an angle exists between the filament axis and the graphene layers have been studied (CNF and FC). These materials show specific surface areas ranging between 70 and 300 m2·g−1. These supports, and particularly sCNF and FC, present a higher prismatic surface area than the other ones. We have found a correlation of the reactivity of the prismatic surface to the average angle of the graphene layers with respect to the filament axis. Higher angles result in higher reactivity of the edges. The possibility to have different concentrations of opened and closed (loops) edges should also be considered. On such supports, the dispersion is generally high, and will be affected by the surface reactivity and area. Hence, the nitric acid oxidation may improve the loading if the reactivity of the edges is high enough. Finally, our study on myrcene hydrogenation allows us to draw some structure/performance correlations. First, the use of supports with high long-range order, such as CNT or FLG, results in lower catalytic activities for this reaction. Higher mean apparent STY were obtained on sCNF, FC and CNF supports, indicating a crucial role of the support structure on the catalytic performance. This should be correlated to the presence of higher amounts of oxygen surface groups, but also to a higher non-basal plane surface on these latter supports, and not necessarily to higher metal dispersion. Indeed, we noticed that the mean apparent STY values increased with the Pd dispersion, but also with the concentration of oxygen surface groups and non-basal plane surface. The introduction of sulfur or nitrogen functionalities, in the case of CNT, does not result in a significant improvement of the mean apparent STY values for the resulting catalysts. We propose that the oxygen surface groups play a role in increasing the surface acidity of the support (particularly through remaining carboxylic groups). This could assist myrcene or intermediate isomerization from hard-to-reduce internal CC bonds into more easily reducible terminal CC bonds. We did not find evidence of a clear correlation between the concentration of oxygen surface groups and/or non-basal plane surface and the electronic state of palladium. Further studies are in course to elucidate the influence of the non-basal plane surface on the intrinsic activity of these Pd/C catalysts for this hydrogenation reaction. coredata.dc:description: The influence of the carbon support characteristics on Pd loading, dispersion and activity in Pd/C catalysts has been analyzed. Several carbon nanomaterials, including multi-walled CNTs, nitrogen-doped CNTs, sulfur-doped CNTs, large- and small-diameter nanofibers, few-layer graphene, and a fibrous carbon have been produced, functionalized, defunctionalized and characterized using several techniques (e.g., nitrogen adsorption, Raman spectroscopy, XPS, TGA, and elemental analysis). These supports present different surface chemistry, arising from different features (defect concentration, inter-defect distances, long-range order, and orientation of the graphene layers) and specific surface areas. The most relevant parameters were obtained by characterization of the materials by Raman, XPS, nitrogen adsorption, and XRD. Twenty-four palladium catalysts with the same nominal loading (2%w/w) were prepared by wet impregnation using an acetone solution of Pd nitrate. These 24 catalysts were characterized by ICP, XRD, XPS and TEM. The final Pd loading varied between 1 and 2%w/w and the Pd particle size ranged from 1.5 to 3.3 nm, depending on the nature of the support. The parameters influencing both Pd loading and dispersion are discussed, and their very high activity for the myrcene complete hydrogenation are reported.
coredata.dc:title: Effect of mesoporous carbon support nature and pretreatments on palladium loading, dispersion and apparent catalytic activity in hydrogenation of myrcene
